Dear Ms. Allen-Pettway:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on (date). Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Implementation,
Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
One out of three applicable special evaluations reviewed did not contain a letter to
the foster parent notifying them of the basis of the extension and expected length of
extension regarding their special evaluation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(4) Before completion of the written report required by subrule
(6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster parent with a
verbal summary of the preliminary findings at the conclusion of
the evaluation.
One out of three special evaluations reviewed contained a verbal summary and
completion of report on the same date.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(h) Recommendations regarding licensing action and any
required corrective action.
4

One out of three special evaluations reviewed did not contain a written report within
15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation. It is noted that the preliminary findings
occurred on 06/20/2018, whereas the report was completed on 10/05/2018.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
One out of three special evaluations reviewed did not contain evidence of the case
manager being given a copy of report.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
One out of three special evaluations reviewed did not contain evidence of the case
manager being notified that there is a corrective action plan and of what is required
of the foster parent in the plan.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12
months before placement or a new physical
examination shall be completed within 30 calendar
days after placement.
5

One out of eight foster care records reviewed contained a physical examination
beyond 30 calendar days after placement. The child was placed on 08/16/2018
whereas the examination was completed on 09/21/2018, six days late.
Repeat Citation from 11/20/2017 renewal inspection report
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed did not contain a modified
service plan with 30 days of the change in agency responsibility.
Repeat Citation from 11/20/2017 renewal inspection report
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
One out of eight adoption records reviewed did not contain evidence of a signed and
dated copy of the evaluation being given to the adoptive applicants.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
23 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
6

The agency has seven relative licensing applicants which have not been licensed
within 180 days of placement. Two have been submitted for licensure requiring an
addendum, one has been submitted as a denial, one has requested a waiver, one
withdrew, whereas one has income and connection issues, and one having
numerous DHHS 24-hour intakes.
Repeat Citation from 11/20/2017 renewal inspection report
ISEP 6.30 Page Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
27
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain a face-to-face meeting
between the supervisor and case manager before approving the service plan.
Supervision is noted as occurring on 09/06/2018, whereas the report was completed
on 10/15/2018.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 Page
11-13
The medical passport shall be updated quarterly.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain an updated quarterly
medical passport between 05-08/2018.
Repeat Citation from 11/20/2017 renewal inspection report
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visit Caseworker Contact with
FOM 722-6H – Caregivers.
Page 7
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there are two
caregivers, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
7

caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home
every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in
MiSACWIS
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain evidence of quarterly
unannounced home visits as occurring for the report periods ending on 05/30/2018
and 08/08/2018.
Repeat Citation from 11/20/2017 renewal inspection report
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s) / Guardian(s)
FOM 722-06H
Page 10
During the first month of out of home placement, the caseworker
must have at least two face-to-face contacts with each
parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in the parent’s
residence. During subsequent months, the caseworker must
have face-to-face contact with each parent/guardian at least
once each calendar month, with at least one contact in each
quarter occurring in the parent’s place of residence.
Three out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed did not contain
documentation of birth parent home visits occurring within the first 30-days of
placement.
Repeat Citation from 11/20/2017 renewal inspection report
FOM DHHS Family Team Meeting
Policy 722-06B
page 1-7
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
One foster care record noted in the analyst report did not include the foster parent in
family team meetings dated 01/04/2018, 04/26/2018, 07/18/2018, and 08/10/2018.
8

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(a) All changes to the factual information contained in the
initial evaluation and subsequent renewal evaluations.
It is noted that a foster child was not included within the bedroom count and
occupants within a reevaluation. All household members are to be included within
the bedroom count and occupants listed.
CI 16-019 Flint water catchment area
For foster homes located in the Flint water catchment area, did
the worker document that they observed water filters in the
home and a system for changing cartridges.
One licensing file is noted as being in Flint on the license. The case record contains
a signed copy of the safety and planning form, which states the home is not in the
city of Flint, but rather is in the Flint Township. It is recommended that the annual
reevaluation contain a statement regarding the home not being within the catchment
area.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(d) Notify all social service workers who have children placed
in the home that a special evaluation has been initiated.
It is recommended that the section of the reevaluation that notes the case managers
and date they were informed of a special evaluation being initiated be completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
9

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The agency developed a corrective action plan to include additional foster
parent training in behavioral management.
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan for the 11/20/2017
renewal inspection report. It appropriately addressed the following as no repeat
citations are noted: ICHAT in personnel file, annual staff performance evaluation,
job description, reevaluation notification to foster parent, reevaluation license more
than 15 days, borrowed home orientation, CPS involvement noted in report, foster
child information to foster parent, timely initial service plan, adoption evaluation
completed within 90 days, MiSACWIS entries, medical authorization card,
documenting sibling visitations, timely intent to adopt forms, and timely MARE photo
upload. Repeat citations include the following: late physical examination, modified
service plan, relative 180-day licensed, quarterly medical passports, unannounced
home visits, birth parent home visits,
The 07/09/2018 analyst report was reviewed and follow up to concerns are as
follows:
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Safety issue: The foster parent does not have an alarm on the sliding door which
leads outside. There is a pool in the backyard.
Resolution: The foster parents attached a door alarm two days
after the analyst visit and the foster parents have consequently
taken the pool down. A resolved safety and concern alert are on
file.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
Concern: The 3-year-old child who is placed does not have a bed frame. She
is currently sleeping on a mattress on the floor. This was addressed
with the foster parent while in the home.
Resolution: The foster parent placed the mattress on a bedframe
four days after the analyst visit. A resolved safety and concern
alert are on file.
Concern: The foster care worker does not make monthly home visits.
10

Resolution: Case record review notes home visits occurring on
12/21/2017, 01/22/2018, 02/24/2018, 03/08/2018, 04/19/2018,
05/11/2018, 06/12/2018, 07/09/2018, 08/17/2018, 09/21/2018,
10/02/2018, and 11/12/2018. It is also noted that the foster parent
signed all child visit tools which documented the home visits.
Concern: The foster care worker does not make unannounced home visits.
Resolution: Case record review notes unannounced visits
occurring on 01/22/2018, 04/19/2018, and 08/17/2018.
Concern: The foster parents have not participated in at least one Family
Team Meeting
Resolution: Case record review notes family team meetings
occurring on 01/04/2018, 04/26/2018, 07/18/2018, and 08/10/2018.
The foster parents are not listed as attending. The agency was
cited as non-compliant.
Concern: The foster parent does not have medical passport for the children
placed in the home.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the foster parent signing
receipt of a medical passport on 01/04/2018.
Safety and Concern Alert #3:
Safety issue: There was a bow & arrow observed in the basement. The safety
concern was addressed with the foster parent during the visit.
Resolution: The agency confirmed that the foster parent placed
the bow in a case and within a locked storage cabinet and the
arrows in a separately locked case two days after the analyst visit.
The facility developed a corrective action plan with the foster parent
for not informing them of the bow and arrow. A resolved safety and
concern alert are on file.
Concern: The foster parent does not have socket covers in the family room
where the children play.
Resolution: The agency confirmed that the foster parent placed
outlet covers on the sockets in the family room two days after the
analyst visit. The facility developed a corrective action plan with the
foster parent. A resolved safety and concern alert are on file.
Concern: The birth parent stated that she is not notified about her children’s
11

routine medical and school appointments or emergencies, nor is
she invited to attend these appointments. One child is 8 years of
age and the other is 3 weeks old.
Resolution: Case record review, via text message screen shots,
between case manager and birth mother indicates birth mother
being aware of medical and emergency appointments.
Concern: The birth parent stated that she does not get to be involved in the
decisions made about her children’s care.
Resolution: Case record review indicates birth mother has gone
against physician’s treatment and recommendations.
Concern: The birth parent reported that she has not reviewed, provided input,
or signed a case services plan with the caseworker.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the agency does not
have family responsibility over birth mother’s case and that the
agency is only responsible for the foster child’s case services.
Concern: The birth parent states the worker does not talk to her about needs
or services for 2 of her children who are placed through the agency
for services. The parent said that her caseworker does not make
her own assessments of these children’s needs or coordinate her
case plan with the caseworker of her older children.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the agency does not
have family responsibility over birth mother’s case. It is noted that
the foster child receives individual therapy through the agency.
Safety and Concern Alert #4:
Safety issue: Infant's crib had mobile attached. Foster parent removed mobile
during the visit after analyst explained the safe sleep risks
associated with toys or mobiles that are attached to cribs. Analyst
advised that DCWL discourages the use of these items due to the
hazards they may pose to infants. Foster parent stated that neither
the licensing worker nor foster care worker commented on the
mobile in the crib.
Resolution: It is not a licensing violation for a crib to have a mobile
attached. The foster parents took down the mobile after the analyst
advised them of DCWL’s stance on discouraging the use of them.
Agency workers did not comment on the mobile as it did not pose a
risk to the child’s health or well-being.
12

Safety and Concern Alert #5:
Safety issue: The home has enough beds and bedrooms for the occupants. The
2 sisters placed in the home, however, refuse to sleep in separate
beds. The foster home has 3 bedrooms with beds available and
have offered this to the 2 sisters. The foster parents state that the
agency is aware of this. No variance was found in the database for
this sleeping arrangement.
Resolution: The foster home has identified beds for all children
placed in the home which does not require a variance. The related
foster children are noted as having past trauma and are comforted
through the current sleeping arrangements. The children will
eventually sleep in their own beds as their past issues of trauma
are addressed.
Safety and Concern Alert #6:
Safety issue/Concern: None
Resolution: None required.
Safety and Concern Alert #7:
Concern: Child does not have enough clothing for cold weather, particularly
winter. Child has been in the home 5 weeks. Foster parent stated
she needs help with getting enough winter clothing for child. Foster
parent said she purchased a large supply of clothing for the
summer due to child having grown out of clothing purchased by the
previous foster parent. Foster parent said she will purchase more
but expressed concern that she will not be able to afford the supply
that the child needs. Child has no boots, gloves, hats, coats,
sweaters, or cold weather clothing.
Resolution: Administrative financial case record review indicates
the foster parent being paid the fall clothing allowance for the foster
child on 09/06/2018 in the amount of $107. It is also noted that the
daily administrative rate paid to foster parent is to be used for
clothing and other accrued household expenses.
13

Safety and Concern Alert #8:
Safety issue/Concern: None
Resolution: None required.
Safety and Concern Alert #9:
Concern: The children’s medication review that was scheduled 2 weeks prior
to the analyst home visit was cancelled and has not yet been
rescheduled.
Resolution: The foster parent is noted as cancelling the child’s
medication review and is responsible for rescheduling.
Concern: The relative request some information about the multiple diagnoses
documented for the children in her care. The diagnoses include
post-traumatic stress disorder, attention-deficit/hyperactivity
disorder, other specified bipolar and related disorder, oppositional
defiant disorder, depression/anxiety, and learning disability.
Resolution: The foster parent was instructed by the case manager
to request information pertaining the foster child’s diagnoses from
the therapist currently working with the child and family.
Concern: The girls have not been receiving therapy due to the departure of
their most recent psychotherapist. A new referral for therapy has
not been made.
Resolution: It is noted that no new referral needs to be made by
the case manager. The foster parent was instructed to contact the
treatment center to transfer therapists.
14

VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
